NARUTO’S FIERCE LADIES COMMENT FICATHON


THE RULES:
  1. IS “X” A FIERCE LADY? Any girl, woman, or lady in the Naruto fandom is a fierce lady. This ficathon is about empowering the women in Naruto because, for some reason or another, Kishimoto does not enjoy fierce ladies much.

  2. How does it work? Lave a comment with the character’s name. If you want, you can request pairings or stories about just that one character. Leave a prompt with specific requests if you want to. If you want her in a ship, write down the other character’s name(s), and a small request. Yaoi and yuri are welcomed. Het, too.


    3. Example 1:
    Sakura. SasuSaku
    in our bedroom after the war

    Example 2:
    Tsunade.
    the sky is burning

    ETA: Add your requests as a new comment, do not request them under the questions/or "x" fierce lady threads as the authors won't be able to see them. Again, REQUESTS ARE UNDER NEW COMMENTS. 

  3. You want to write the request/fic, now what? As the author of the fic, please put in the title (of the comment) FEMALE CHARACTER’S NAME. SHIP (OPTIONAL). TITLE OF FIC. RATING (IF APPLICABLE).

  4. NO MALE CHARACTERS AS THE MAIN CHARACTERS. This is about fierce women, so request the story to be about a certain female character. You can have men in your stories, they just can’t be the main character of the small fic. However, the story could be from a man’s point of view.

  5. WHAT ABOUT ART? If you have a special request for a drawing, just leave add “(ART)” at the end of your request. 

  6. LEAVE FEEDBACK. Authors love comments and it increases chances of them writing more fic which supply readers with flailing moments of happiness.

  7. NO HATERS. This is an open ficathon, if you’re going to hate, I suggest you move to the left since I will delete any and all sorts of hate comments. You don’t like? Then don’t come, it’s that simple.

  8. If you have art and would like to contribute, you’re more than welcome to send me a message so I can post it. 

  9. Promote this! If you want, that is. The more the merrier.

Title: in our bedroom after the war
Fandom: Naruto
Rating: R/NC-17
Summary: Sasuke and Sakura as they should be.
Disclaimer: I do not own Naruto.
Warning: It's Sasuke and Sakura, I don't know what kind of warning I should give. Just -- be ready to tear up? Maybe.





Wake up, say good morning to
That sleepy person lying next to you.
If there's no one there, then there's no one there,
But at least the war is over.
- Stars



“Take me with you!”

The same words that she had said years ago as a girl echoed again. But now she was a woman, a shinobi. He meant to tell her off – nothing good ever came from him, after all, but the pain in his body prevented him from doing so and he hissed as he fell to the ground knee-first.

“Who are you?” Karin managed to ask, face frozen in confusion and terror.

Sakura swallowed and turned to Sasuke – there was nothing she could do for the girl anyway. She needed to gain Sasuke’s trust and if it meant letting the girl on the floor, then she had to. Even if it went against her morals as a medic. “I know all of Komoha’s secrets. Sasuke-kun, this time, let me help you.”

“Why?” He asked.

She didn’t hesitate, “Because Kakashi is on his way and I can help you escape.”

“Hn.”

“I can help you. You need me and you don’t want to admit it,” she said as she walked up to him. Holding her hand out to him, she pleaded, “Sasuke.”

Karin looked bewildered at Sasuke’s trust in the newcomer. She felt the girl’s eye on her and turned to see her face. Sakura, she thinks she heard Sasuke say, leaned down and whispered to her.

“I’m so sorry.”

Karin felt a slight tingle run across her body. The last thing she saw was Sasuke and Sakura running to the West.

--//--

“We’ll stay here for the night, she said as she entered the small inn. She had removed her headband and changed her hair color. He admitted he would have liked black on her, but she chose brown for both of them.

They started holding hands at some point between crossing the border and forgetting their chosen paths.

Once in the bedroom, she sat him down and started tearing at his clothes, looking for his critical injuries first.

“Why did you come after me?”

“I already told you why.”

“Why.”

“Because I love you,” and he noticed how for the first time there was a hint of regret in her words. “I’m almost done healing you.”

“You shouldn’t. Everyone who loves me dies. Itachi – he loved and I killed him. But he loved – he loved me and died because of me,” he had never sounded so mortified.

“I know. I read everything.” His questioning gaze made Sakura confess her discovery of the massacre and the Council’s lies. “That’s why I’m here.”

That’s when Sasuke pulled her to him; meeting in a silent sigh. Neither of them thought of the past or their 12-year-old selves. Sasuke took his time in exploring this new woman willing to do anything to save him again. It’s unexpected, but Sakura allowed him to take control.

Sakura felt fine then, or so she thought. At least, his kisses made her forget what was to come. Sakura placed her hand over his heart and looked up at him, “Everything will be alright, now Sasuke-kun. I’m here.” Without a second thought, she pushed him to the bed and took off her shirt. It was getting tougher having to control her gasps. “Do you -- are you okay with this?”

Sasuke gulped as he nodded and if it was any other situation, she might have laughed.

She pressed her lips harder against him in an attempt to control herself. Sakura wondered if Sasuke could feel the desperation or maybe mistook it as his own. Either way, they didn’t care as the moved against each other. She kissed her way up to his ear and whispered promises to him.

“I will never leaver you – never.”

Sakura removed the rest of his clothes, along with her pants. She looked back at Sasuke to make sure things were alright, but he only smirked and flipped them over. “Hn.”

Without further notice, he entered her in one swift motion. Sakura moaned and it made Sasuke worry if it had been from pain or pleasure, but when he moved again, she closed her eyes and pulled him closer – her legs pressing his buttocks. It had definitely been pleasure.

In all their clumsiness, they found each other’s hands. Never had they ever felt closer to life than at that instant when they held each other.

Sakura gasped, “I love you so much.”

“I know.” He said as he bent down to kiss her at the peak of their climax.

As it should be.

--//--

“Rest now,” Sakura told Sasuke as she got up from bed. “I’ll take care – I’ll watch out for both of us.”

Sasuke laid back down and closed his eyes, looking forward to Konoha in the morning. Hours after, Sakura took the courage to lay next to Sasuke. He slept peacefully, not frowning or with caution as he had when they were genin. He trusted her now.

She clamped her hand over her mouth to stop her sobs. No use crying now, she told herself, things had to be done. Using her fingertips, she hovered over Sasuke’s chest, not knowing where to start. Her determination and love took the better part of her, and her fingertips pressed against his heart. The green glow was the only light in the room. Sasuke slept quietly as Sakura controlled his circulation and then, just like war, there was no light.

--//--

Kakashi found her crying on the bathroom floor.

He might argue that it's a way for governments to set limits to people because they would, in a way, depend on government. HP love because it's too good and I miss it. Oh, HHr! So. Class reaction: The Article we had to read for class: written in a Conservative Think Tank. Thoughts? Why would they do that? Perhaps it's a way of affirm their believes? Je ne sais pas. Also, Burke would approve. He's argue that it's okay to take advantage of people because there are smarter folks out there that need to rule the other citizens. Oh, Tradition, Burke approves. Wealth of Nations: Smith
  1. What's good for society will ultimately be good for everyone.
  2. Small businesses would never get profit if it wasn't for governmental services. Post office, security (police, firefighters, etc.). We need government because businesses don't teach people how to read.
  3. Unlike the first French Constitution (the one that lasted for only a year), the United States failed to make everyone within its borders a citizen. If followed Montesquieu's philosophy too much. Smith would not have approved.

In this part, I read more into the reasons of Burke's dislike of the French Revolution or any revolution. 

He writes, with much dislike, how a revolution against the state is an act of liberty. In all honesty, he believes that even the talks of starting a revolution, destroys the people's security and welfare. He associates it with taking periodical doses of mercury and "swallowing down repeated provocatives of cantharides" (101).  This man has an intense dislike of revolutions. It makes sense, though, that he preferred the American Revolution because they did fight for more liberty, and perhaps because they, in a way, tried to maintain a way of tradition. The tradition to Americans would have been living without taxation, maintaining their liberal ideologies of the market and of the state they wanted to form.

Q: Why is Burke considered the father of Conservatism?

My response: I believe he valued the idea of the state and the leader to be all supreme and powerful (also a reason why he disliked the French Revolution -- peasants killed their nobles). There is also a quote where he believes succession to be one of the most valuable acts a kingdom or state could follow. (Note: it seems very familiar to the Mandate of Heaven in Chinese Dynasties). With succession, it reassured who would be leader and no one would want to fight against that right. Also, succession of power would guarantee the support of the people if the previous leader served their state.


We also discussed that
  • He was likely to be considered the Father of Conservatism because Conservatists likely believed in systems that were already in place, ie. a monarchy.
  • Moral attitude! He believed in an organic way of life being a critical part to community and self.
  • The concept of individual was foolish. One needed to preserve tradition overall and stay away from irrationality. This also links back to the idea his concepts were similar to the Mandate of Heaven and Confucian ideology. He could've studied Chinese ideologies, maybe.

I shall use my Marie Antoinette icon in honor of Burke and his love for the French Revolution. :D

He really did not like the French Revolution for they went against the well constructed state Burke argues France had. Although it would appear that he disliked all sorts of revolutions against a formed state, Burke only seems to object against the French Revolution. We find in the articles that he did approve and support the American Revolution. After reading the first parts, I think he approved of the American Revolution because they wanted to form their own state. Great Britain would not want to secure all of their colonies, hence the Americans would have a justification to revolt.

• Rousseau really loves community. Community be over self interest, he says.
  • The Majestry (government) reinforces laws while sovereign - the people - make laws.
  • City-states would be more beneficial and easier to governed than large territories since it means a small community that not only shares a region but culture, economics among some other things. I think it would make better sense, and it does imply that the United States cannot run their politics with a community-base background as much  since we are such a big nation. I'm not suggesting that the United States should not be so big, it does have its benefits. However, if we try to become a tighter community, it's harder to achieve since all of the regions and cultures we have in the country. Does this mean it should affect who becomes a citizen?
  • Climate also affects the way a government functions, writes Rousseau! It's really incredible that he writes about the environment and the potential problems and awareness it needs from the government so long ago. It's still going on today. For instance, here we would worry more about climate change. However, India would worry more about their birth rates and how they could feed all the people. China would think about the use of carbon and the effects on the environment. It all depends on the different agencies.

There's an artificial body of government, meaning that Rousseau actually addresses the fact that government is a theoretical thought, not something solid that one can hold. Therefore, Rousseau addresses the fact that because the government is made up of representatives chosen by people. I like the fact that Rousseau sees and raises awareness to the fact that people might not follow up on their government after they have already chosen their representatives since they just leave it to them to handle their rights. Although, I'm not the best example, we can really see that people have taken their right to participate in governments and left them in Washington. We should really take up to Rousseau and continue our work as citizens.

Then again, if we do have the privilege to vote if we want to, why even bother, correct? Sometimes I believe we do have to go out there and participate. It is essential to our every day life style because every day we are faced with things that can affect us if we hadn't taken that action. I shouldn't compare it to Peruvian politics -- the fact that they fine those who don't vote -- but sometimes it would be a good act, a legitimate act to have everyone vote. Even though we imagine people would vote for their desired leader, do we really believe they are? It might not change anything at the beginning; people might still vote for the lesser of two evils. Or they might not.

Rousseau writes:
"Every man is born free and everywhere he is in chains."
I think it means that in liberty one has the freedom to decide on life but within the contract, the social contract with the state. Therefore, there will always be certain laws that would prevent one from being completely free. It goes back to Hobbes' argument that laws actually limit or freedom.
Examples:
  • Free to belong to any organization, except those with the determination to harm others. The KKK. Even though it is free to exist, they are still within the jurisdictions of not hurting other people because of their race, etc. 
  • To write freely on the press as long as it doesn't interfere with the welfare of the people.
And many, many more.

Book I.

The state has the right and needs to take care of the people. According to Rousseau, the State becomes master of all good, meaning that it has the obligation to take care of their people and of their liberties. There's also something mentioned about the "first occupier". I don't really follow Rousseau on this as I'm not sure if he's talking about citizenship or not. If he is, however, then it implies that there should be right to those citizens that the government needs to fulfill. 

Book II. 

Something that caught my attention more than anything else was Rousseau's Sec 5 - The Right to Life and Death.
It's incredible how something from the past can still have its effects today and I'm not being sarcastic or anything this time. In all honesty, it is something more than brilliant that when Rousseau writes about the state also having the decision to someone's life we still see it today. For instance, if the police catches someone about to commit suicide, then it becomes the federal or state obligation to stop said act and actually punish someone with a fine (or something else) for attempting murder on one's own self, or property. It is because of the social contract that the state needs to protect such life. 

I also like the fact that he does not believe in the death penalty as it would turn the state to murderer too. Anyone really who attacks the rights of people become or should be seen as committing a crime. Then again, not everyone followed or actually paid much attention to this when slavery was advocated.

Once again, we discussed about Majority rule and how Locke advocates for this majority because it is the ideal governed self. However, who makes up this majority? In fact, it is a minority of the people the ones that made up the majority to Locke (and in some cases, still do today). White men were the majority and the voice of the people since women could not speak up and black men had no rights. Therefore, in order to really evaluate who makes up this ideal self-governed being, we have to look at who it is or who it should be to Locke. I discussed this on my paper and hopefully it is addressed coherently.

We also discussed if the government acts in our best public interest. If they do, then do we affect another country's public interest? We do it today with our garbage; we allow people  to take our garbage and then we forget about it. But really, we just send it to other countries.

However, I shall make the attempt.

Government should only exist to protect our property, yay! If I don't have a big house though, can I not get the same protection? Boohoo. Although sometimes we think that more property means more care, we should also evaluate the person. For instance, I do not believe it should be legal that if you live in a public housing you have no right to your home and the government could barge it and do whatever. Yeah, it is public housing, but people still need their privacy and their security. Government serves our security, after all, and the self could be our property so the government should protect that as well. Right?

Let's not say goodbye to our rights.
